Key Point

The symbol \(i\) is such that \[i^2=-1.\] Using the normal rules of algebra it follows that \[i^3=i^2\times i=-i\qquad i^4=i^2\times i^2=(-1)\times (-1)=1\] and so on.

Simple examples of complex numbers are \(\qquad z_1=3+2i \quad\qquad z_2=-3+(2.461)i\quad\qquad z_3=17i \quad\qquad z_4=3+0i = 3\)

Generally, if \(z=a+i b\) then ‘\(a\)’ is called the real part of \(z\), or Re(\(z\)) for short, and ‘ \(b\)’ is called the imaginary part of \(z\) or Im(\(z)\) for short. Notice how both the real and imaginary parts are real numbers. The fourth example indicates how the real numbers can be considered a subset of the complex numbers.
